feed.title: Study blog
feed.subtitle: This website is presenting projects and apps created while taking a formal training in Computer Science and programming. Here I will store projects and labs done in programming courses as well as some of the materials required according to curriculum.

entry.title: Another post created with jekyll
entry.content:
Header

Something happened to Gemfile or it contents. I am not able to run a development server. Have to edit the website directly from github. This is fine for content writing, but it kind of inconvenient to perform other tasks.
entry.summary: Header Something happened to Gemfile or it contents. I am not able to run a development server. Have to edit the website directly from github. This is fine for content writing, but it kind of inconvenient to perform other tasks.

entry.title: First post create with jekyll
entry.content:
This is a first post crated with a use of a bloging platform created by github.

It doesn’t contain much information, hence showcasing how it could be done in a most simple way.
entry.summary: This is a first post crated with a use of a bloging platform created by github.

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
